title.value: Shared and unique brain network features predict cognitive, personality, and mental health scores in the ABCD study
title.justification: The title clearly reflects the study's focus on predicting cognitive, personality, and mental health scores using brain network features from the ABCD study.
title.quote: Shared and unique brain network features predict cognitive, personality, and mental health scores in the ABCD study

extractions.description: This study explores how differences in brain network organization can predict behavioral variability, specifically in cognitive, personality, and mental health domains, using the ABCD study's dataset of typically developing children.

type.justification: The paper uses data from the ABCD study and applies machine learning algorithms to predict various behavioral outcomes, indicating an empirical research approach.
type.quote: In a large sample of 1858 typically developing children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study, we show that predictive network features are distinct across the domains of cognitive performance, personality scores and mental health assessments.

name.justification: The study is primarily concerned with understanding brain network features and their predictive power for behavioral traits, which is central to neuroscience.
name.quote: How individual differences in brain network organization track behavioral variability is a fundamental question in systems neuroscience.

name.justification: The study focuses on brain development in typically developing children, which is a core aspect of neurodevelopmental research.
name.quote: Childhood is a period of rapid neural development and behavioral changes across cognition, personality, and mental health.

name.justification: The research utilizes functional connectivity (both resting and task-based) to predict behavioral traits, placing it within this subfield.
name.quote: Whole-brain connectome-wide neurodevelopmental studies have found associations between resting-state functional network organization and behavioral traits.

name.justification: Kernel regression is mentioned as the method used for behavioral prediction based on brain network features.
name.quote: We used kernel regression to predict each behavioral measure based on resting FC, MID-FC, SST-FC, and N-back FC separately.

is_contributed.justification: Kernel regression is a standard method used in the analysis, not contributed by the authors.
is_contributed.quote: We used kernel regression to predict each behavioral measure based on resting FC, MID-FC, SST-FC, and N-back FC separately.

is_executed.justification: The kernel regression model was executed as part of the study to perform predictions.
is_executed.quote: The regression model was fitted on the training set and used to predict behavior in the test set.

is_compared.justification: Kernel regression performance was compared to other methods, like linear regression, to assess prediction accuracy.
is_compared.quote: We obtained similar prediction performance, but linear regression achieved worse COD (Supplementary Fig. 19).

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep neural networks and kernel regression achieve comparable accuracies for functional connectivity prediction of behavior and demographics
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper is referenced concerning the use of kernel regression for behavioral prediction.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Kernel regression is a powerful approach for resting-FC behavioral prediction ^{54}.

name.justification: The ABCD study dataset is central to the analysis performed in this research.
name.quote: In a large sample of 1858 typically developing children from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study...

referenced_paper_title.value: The conception of the ABCD study: From substance use to a broad NIH collaboration
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper is about the ABCD study, which provides the dataset used.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Volkow, N. D. et al. The conception of the ABCD study: From substance use to a broad NIH collaboration.
